newsitem.title: USA: U.S. space shuttle fueled for launch.
newsitem.headline: U.S. space shuttle fueled for launch.

text.p: Engineers began fuelling the space shuttle Columbia on Friday for an afternoon blastoff on a 16-day science mission to study fire in space, NASA officials said.
Columbia was scheduled to lift off from Florida's Kennedy Space Centre at 2 p.m. EST (1900 GMT).

Launch controllers began pumping half a million gallons of supercold liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen into the shuttle's rust-coloured strap-on fuel tank shortly after 6 a.m. EST (1100 GMT), NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said.

The fuelling operation was held up for about an hour while engineers checked for a possible problem with one of Columbia's three electricity-generating fuel cells. The device had shown some unusual voltage readings but later returned to normal.
"They are going to continue to monitor it, but there was enough confidence in the fuel cell to proceed with the countdown," Buckingham said.
There was sufficient slack in the countdown schedule to accommodate the late fuelling without delaying the shuttle's liftoff, he said.
The crew of seven were due to start boarding Columbia, NASA's oldest shuttle, at around 11:15 a.m. EST (1615 GMT).

During their 16 days aloft, the astronauts will work around the clock in two shifts in a laboratory module mounted in the shuttle's cargo bay. They will light more than 200 fires in a specially designed chamber to learn more about how flames behave in space and on the earth.
Other experiments will attempt to determine the structure of proteins associated with various diseases and develop new, stronger materials.
Excellent weather was forecast for the shuttle's 2-1/2 hour launch window. Meteorologists predicted a 90 percent chance of acceptable weather.
Tens of thousands of tourists were expected to line the roads around the Kennedy Space Centre to watch the shuttle's rare afternoon blastoff, which coincides with school holidays.
The shuttle would also provide an unexpected flying display for visitors to an air show at nearby Patrick Air Force Base.
"It'll give those spectators something else to watch," shuttle operations director Bob Sieck said.

Columbia's launch was running a day late because engineers had to install thermal insulation missing from pipes in the shuttle's cooling system, a problem that may have gone undetected for more than 13 years.
